margin: 0in 0in 0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; mso-pagination: none; text-align: justify;\"><br />\n</div><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">  </span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: normal; margin: 0in 0in 0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; mso-pagination: none; text-align: justify;\"><span style=\"mso-bidi-font-family: Calibri;\"><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">Chemical tanker men work on low freeboard decks at sea for MANUAL tankcleaning in cold icy winds and sea spray or they could be wearing nil-ventilated PPE in hot weather in port in direct sunlight, doing stripping or manual valve topping up.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">  </span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: normal; margin: 0in 0in 0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; mso-pagination: none; text-align: justify;\"><br />\n</div><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">  </span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: normal; margin: 0in 0in 0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; mso-pagination: none; text-align: justify;\"><span style=\"mso-bidi-font-family: Calibri;\"><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">Knowledge of effect of heat and cold on human body is important to prevent LTI and ill effects to health.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">  </span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: normal; margin: 0in 0in 0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; mso-pagination: none; text-align: justify;\"><br />\n</div><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">  </span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: normal; margin: 0in 0in 0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; mso-pagination: none; text-align: justify;\"><span style=\"mso-bidi-font-family: Calibri;\"><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">Master must do a risk assessment when there are chances of heat or cold stress to his crew.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">  </span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: normal; margin: 0in 0in 0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; mso-pagination: none; text-align: justify;\"><br />\n</div><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">  </span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: normal; margin: 0in 0in 0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; mso-pagination: none; text-align: justify;\"><b style=\"mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;\"><span style=\"mso-bidi-font-family: Calibri;\"><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">HEAT STRESS:<o:p></o:p></span></span></b></div><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">  </span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: normal; margin: 0in 0in 0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; mso-pagination: none; text-align: justify;\"><div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-FfXg1iTZjG0/TkO7Ql0d3eI/AAAAAAAAFQ4/OYSltEsvH30/s1600/untitled.png\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-FfXg1iTZjG0/TkO7Ql0d3eI/AAAAAAAAFQ4/OYSltEsvH30/s1600/untitled.png\" /></a></div><br />\n</div><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">  </span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: normal; margin: 0in 0in 0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; mso-pagination: none; text-align: justify;\"><span style=\"mso-bidi-font-family: Calibri;\"><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">Elevated humidity or wearing chemical resistant splash suits reduces the ability of the body to evaporate the sweat and cool it, and increases the heat load . This can be made worse by radiant heat of the sun while on deck. <o:p></o:p></span></span></div><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">  </span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: normal; margin: 0in 0in 0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; mso-pagination: none; text-align: justify;\"><br />\n</div><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">  </span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: normal; margin: 0in 0in 0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; mso-pagination: none; text-align: justify;\"><span style=\"mso-bidi-font-family: Calibri;\"><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">Heat rashes can even affect sleep , during off duty hours.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">  </span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: normal; margin: 0in 0in 0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; mso-pagination: none; text-align: justify;\"><div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-2L76rqtzcT4/TkO8HJULLUI/AAAAAAAAFRY/XKELxozBxPA/s1600/imagesCAYKTL06.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-2L76rqtzcT4/TkO8HJULLUI/AAAAAAAAFRY/XKELxozBxPA/s1600/imagesCAYKTL06.jpg\" /></a></div><br />\n</div><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">  </span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: normal; margin: 0in 0in 0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; mso-pagination: none; text-align: justify;\"><span style=\"mso-bidi-font-family: Calibri;\"><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">Radiant heat could be from<span style=\"mso-spacerun: yes;\">&nbsp; </span>steam coils while squeegeing the cargo inside the tanks. The physical work which has to be done FAST increases the heat load on the body.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">  </span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: normal; margin: 0in 0in 0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; mso-pagination: none; text-align: justify;\"><br />\n</div><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">  </span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: normal; margin: 2.95pt 0in 0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; mso-pagination: none; text-align: justify;\"><span style=\"mso-bidi-font-family: Calibri; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;\"><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">The crew members sent to sweep the tanks must be physically fit , with zero blood alcohol levels. They must keep the body hydrated by drinking water to prevent heat exhaustion. <o:p></o:p></span></span></div><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">  </span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: normal; margin: 2.95pt 0in 0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; mso-pagination: none; text-align: justify;\"><br />\n</div><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">  </span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: normal; margin: 2.95pt 0in 0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; mso-pagination: none; text-align: justify;\"><span style=\"mso-bidi-font-family: Calibri; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;\"><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">Salt tablets can replace the sodium lost from the cells. The sodium is like acid in a car battery\u2019s electrolyte.<span style=\"mso-spacerun: yes;\">&nbsp; </span>Salt depletion can cause debilitating body cramps. <span style=\"letter-spacing: -0.05pt;\">H</span>eat C<span style=\"letter-spacing: 0.05pt;\">r</span>am<span style=\"letter-spacing: -0.05pt;\">p</span>s a<span style=\"letter-spacing: 0.05pt;\">r</span>e pa<span style=\"letter-spacing: -0.05pt;\">in</span>f<span style=\"letter-spacing: -0.05pt;\">u</span>l<span style=\"letter-spacing: -0.05pt;\"> </span>mus<span style=\"letter-spacing: 0.05pt;\">cl</span>e spasms. Roman&quot;, serif;\">  </span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: normal; margin: 2.95pt 0in 0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; mso-pagination: none; text-align: justify;\"><div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-w3sKHqWhI0Y/TkO7Y1IKMzI/AAAAAAAAFQ8/68gTSN5ppAs/s1600/imagesCAB0URPD.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" />\n</div><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">  </span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: normal; margin: 2.95pt 0in 0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; mso-pagination: none; text-align: justify;\"><span style=\"mso-bidi-font-family: Calibri; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;\"><span style=\"font-family: Times, &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, serif;\">Heat stress can cause lack of concentration, irritability, tiredness and poor work performance.<span style=\"mso-spacerun: yes;\">&nbsp; </span>It causes hea<span style=\"letter-spacing: -0.05pt;\">v</span>y<span style=\"letter-spacing: 0.05pt;\"> </span>sweat<span style=\"letter-spacing: -0.05pt;\">in</span><span style=\"letter-spacing: 0.05pt;\">g</span>,<span Ajit Vadakayil", "url": "https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654", "image": {"url": "//4.bp.blogspot.com/-QSnd-Z8F7Kc/XFtPudWdwlI/AAAAAAABfq4/vxrkFOO7Iu8Mf6-OaPgw6FPpRDSmMgLdgCK4BGAYYCw/s35/capt%25252BajitC%25252Bvadakayil.JPG"}}, "replies": {"totalItems": "2", "selfLink": "https://www.googleapis.com/blogger/v3/blogs/3564735312144269387/posts/8942264220963139564/comments"}}, {"kind": "blogger#post", "id": "1662536900740036464", "blog": {"id": "3564735312144269387"}, "published": "2011-08-11T00:49:00+05:30", "updated": "2013-07-16T08:26:08+05:30", "etag": "\"iHf3yWDE_geBgZ8U7rgZ_xuTeAQ/dGltZXN0YW1wOiAxMzczOTQzMzY4ODMxCm9mZnNldDogMTk4MDAwMDAK\"", "url": "http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2011/08/day-before-you-came-capt-ajit-vadakayil.html", "selfLink": "https://www.googleapis.com/blogger/v3/blogs/3564735312144269387/posts/1662536900740036464", "title": "THE DAY BEFORE YOU CAME -- CAPT AJIT VADAKAYIL", "content": "<div dir=\"ltr\" style=\"text-align: left;\" trbidi=\"on\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-WcPMF6gC_xM/TkLfi98GnxI/AAAAAAAAFQA/SVLfMH6yXbw/s1600/imagesCATOJ7M4.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-WcPMF6gC_xM/TkLfi98GnxI/AAAAAAAAFQA/SVLfMH6yXbw/s1600/imagesCATOJ7M4.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<br />\nABBA -- THE MAGNIFICENT<br />\n<br />\nThis was a very unusual poignant&nbsp;song sung by Agnetha of ABBA in 1982-- a timeless classic.&nbsp; <br />\n<br />\nIn my opinion this is the most underrated song ever.&nbsp; <br />\n<br />\nThere is an indirect reference to a man who appeared one fine day and overturned the mundane dull life of an ordinary woman. <br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-8m4_WYNI65Y/TkLfnuk0pnI/AAAAAAAAFQE/893QMEfcfJc/s1600/uk.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-8m4_WYNI65Y/TkLfnuk0pnI/AAAAAAAAFQE/893QMEfcfJc/s1600/uk.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\">Basically it is her own story. </span><br />\n<br />\nThe unsaid is stronger than the worn out usual words.<br />\n<br />\nAs she is singing live on stage she is aware of the&nbsp;piercing and crushing realisation of the impending final split-- and that this is their last lap.<br />\n<br />\nYou can feel the melancholy and see the sadness in her eyes.&nbsp; This is the reason why this song at Saarbrucken Germany is&nbsp;chillingly beautiful and heartbreaking. <br />\n<br />\nIt touches you at the deepest human level. Watch her lip movements and facial expressions.<br />\n<br />\nAgnetha looks so vulnerable, and hurt from her facial expressions-- yet she does not falter on stage. <br />\n<br />\nThe other three can feel her shredded emotions, but they pretend all is hunky dory. Still Bjorn (with red tie) &nbsp;on the guitar looks very sheepish.<br />\n<br />\nSHE PUTS SOUL INTO THIS SONG--<br />\n<br />\n-- rather it is a glorious sunset..<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-LWmn_sSJSWg/TkLfyl0dIJI/AAAAAAAAFQI/9ORj9GlkWi0/s1600/sdf.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-LWmn_sSJSWg/TkLfyl0dIJI/AAAAAAAAFQI/9ORj9GlkWi0/s1600/sdf.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<object class=\"BLOGGER-youtube-video\" classid=\"clsid:D27CDB6E-AE6D-11cf-96B8-444553540000\" codebase=\"http://download.macromedia.com/pub/shockwave/cabs/flash/swflash.cab#version=6,0,40,0\" data-thumbnail-src=\"http://3.gvt0.com/vi/8GAPAvev-os/0.jpg\" height=\"266\" width=\"320\"><param name=\"movie\" value=\"http://www.youtube.com/v/8GAPAvev-os&fs=1&source=uds\" /><param name=\"bgcolor\" value=\"#FFFFFF\" /><embed width=\"320\" height=\"266\"  src=\"http://www.youtube.com/v/8GAPAvev-os&fs=1&source=uds\" type=\"application/x-shockwave-flash\"></embed></object></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"line-height: 13.5pt;\">ABBA was a band formed in 1972 by Frida ( brunette --Anni-Frid Lyngstad) , Anna ( blondie- Agnetha F\u00e4ltskog ) , Benny ( bearded on keyboard --Benny Andersson ) and Bjorn ( guitarist -- Bj\u00f6rn Ulvaeus ). They were married couples . I had seen them live in Australia in 1976.</span><br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in 0in 0pt;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in 0in 12pt;\">\n<span style=\"background: rgb(238, 238, 204); color: #333333; font-family: &quot;Trebuchet MS&quot;,&quot;sans-serif&quot;; font-size: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;; mso-fareast-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;;\">ABBA is the 2nd best selling band in history. They made the best music ever on this planet for 10 years . There can never be another ABBA\u2014 this young and exuberant band ruled the world stage from 1972 to 1982 .</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in 0in 12pt;\">\n<span style=\"background: rgb(238, 238, 204); color: #333333; font-family: &quot;Trebuchet MS&quot;,&quot;sans-serif&quot;; font-size: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;; mso-fareast-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;;\"><br />\nThe English speaking countries lost their vice grip on English pop music. ABBA was 35 weeks on Britain's charts, a feat which can never be beaten.</span><span style=\"background: rgb(238, 238, 204); color: #333333; font-family: &quot;Trebuchet MS&quot;,&quot;sans-serif&quot;; font-size: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;; mso-fareast-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;;\"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in 0in 0pt;\">\n<span style=\"background: rgb(238, 238, 204); color: #333333; font-family: &quot;Trebuchet MS&quot;,&quot;sans-serif&quot;; font-size: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;; mso-fareast-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;;\">The platinum haired Swedish blondie Anna (Agnetha Faltskog), with her gap toothed smile was my favorite -- for she had the<span style=\"color: red; font-size: large;\"> ONE IN A BILLION crystal clear, RICH high pitched voice</span>. ( not like the pathetic THIN voice of our Lata Mangeshkar who can never be popular in any other country except India ). </span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"background: rgb(238, 238, 204); color: #333333; font-family: &quot;Trebuchet MS&quot;,&quot;sans-serif&quot;; font-size: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;; mso-fareast-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;;\">Her voice would ride above and captivate the audience.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"background: rgb(238, 238, 204); color: #333333; font-family: &quot;Trebuchet MS&quot;,&quot;sans-serif&quot;; font-size: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;; mso-fareast-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;;\"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in 0in 0pt;\">\n<span style=\"background: rgb(238, 238, 204); color: #333333; font-family: &quot;Trebuchet MS&quot;,&quot;sans-serif&quot;; font-size: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;; mso-fareast-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;;\">Millions of men were in love with this graceful lady.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in 0in 0pt;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in 0in 0pt;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in 0in 0pt;\">\n<span style=\"background: rgb(238, 238, 204); color: #333333; font-family: &quot;Trebuchet MS&quot;,&quot;sans-serif&quot;; font-size: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;; mso-fareast-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;;\">In 1979 Anna and Bjorn got divorced. The gorgeous blondie Anna was emotionally mangled by the split, as Bjorn took in another woman within a week-.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">leaving their young children\nLinda Elin Ulvaeus and Peter Christian Ulvaeus in the lurch.</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;,&quot;serif&quot;; Brunette Frida and bearded Benny got divorced in 1981.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in 0in 0pt;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in 0in 0pt;\">\n<span style=\"background: rgb(238, 238, 204); color: #333333; font-family: &quot;Trebuchet MS&quot;,&quot;sans-serif&quot;; font-size: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;; mso-fareast-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;;\">In 2000 ABBA turned down an offer of 1 billion US dollars for a reunion tour. because I always do <br />\nMy train, I'm certain, left the station just when it was due <br />\nI must have read the morning paper going into town <br />\nAnd having gotten through the editorial, no doubt I must have frowned <br />\nI must have made my desk around a quarter after nine <br />\nWith letters to be read, and heaps of papers waiting to be signed <br />\nI must have gone to lunch at half past twelve or so <br />\nThe usual place, the usual bunch <br />\nAnd still on top of this I'm pretty sure it must have rained <br />\nThe day before you came <br />\n<br />\nI must have lit my seventh cigarette at half past two <br />\nAnd at the time I never even noticed I was blue <br />\nI must have kept on dragging through the business of the day <br />\nWithout really knowing anything, I hid a part of me away <br />\nAt five I must have left, there's no exception to the rule <br />\nA matter of routine, I've done it ever since I finished school <br />\nThe train back home again <br />\nUndoubtedly I must have read the evening paper then <br />\nOh yes, I'm sure my life was well within its usual frame <br />\nThe day before you came <br />\n<br />\nI must have opened my front door at eight o'clock or so <br />\nAnd stopped along the way to buy some Chinese food to go <br />\nI'm sure I had my dinner watching something on TV <br />\nThere's not, I think, a single episode of Dallas that I didn't see <br />\nI must have gone to bed around a quarter after ten <br />\nI need a lot of sleep, and so I like to be in bed by then <br />\nI must have read a while <br />\nThe latest one by Marilyn French or something in that style <br />\nIt's funny, but I had no sense of living without aim <br />\nThe day before you came <br />\n<br />\nAnd turning out the light I must have yawned and cuddled up for yet another night <br />\nAnd rattling on the roof I must have heard the sound of rain <br />\nThe day before you came<o:p></o:p></span></em></span></div>\n<em><span These subatomic waves or particles not only know about each other , but are also highly interlinked by bands of common electromagnetic fields, so that they can communicate together. It becomes difficult to tell them apart. </span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-qhMrPjkjic0/TkNRaveoTfI/AAAAAAAAFQY/mc-YAAkcA6w/s1600/tf.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-qhMrPjkjic0/TkNRaveoTfI/AAAAAAAAFQY/mc-YAAkcA6w/s1600/tf.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\">Many of the weird quantum effects seen in a single wave apply to the whole. Something done to one of them will affect the others, coherence establishes communication,<span style=\"mso-spacerun: yes;\">&nbsp; </span>some sort of collective vibration was responsible for getting proteins to cooperate with each other and carry out instructions of DNA and cellular proteins.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\">Once energy reaches a certain threshold, molecules begin to vibrate in unison, until they reach a level of coherence. They get to the point where they can operate in tandem.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\">Consciousness is a global phenomenon that occurred everywhere in the body and not just in <span style=\"mso-spacerun: yes;\">&nbsp;</span>our brains. This means they can remain in quantum state, a condition of all possible states, enabling the brain eventually to finally choose among them. This is <span style=\"color: red; font-size: large;\">free will</span>. At every moment our brains are making quantum choices, taking potential states and making them actual ones.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-wJnYXjqDdaI/TkNRyPfCpjI/AAAAAAAAFQc/rybUemsRIKQ/s1600/tf4.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-wJnYXjqDdaI/TkNRyPfCpjI/AAAAAAAAFQc/rybUemsRIKQ/s1600/tf4.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\">Brain processes occurred at the quantum level. Honor killings take place in India with a rigid Khap\nvillage justice system.&nbsp;</b></span></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"line-height: 115%;\"><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times&quot; , &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\"><b><br /></b></span></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"line-height: 115%;\"><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times&quot; , &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\"><b>The Gotra system was designed to track down the root Y\nChromosome of a person . The ancient Vedic Rishis had observed the degeneration\nof the Y Chromosome and they wanted to maintain as many individual healthy\nunique Y Chromosome lineages as possible. That would give a fair chance for\nmales to continue to exist because Y Chromosomes get passed on over generations\nwith almost negligible change in their genetic combinations, as they do not\ntake part in mix and match with other Chromosome.&nbsp;</b></span></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"line-height: 115%;\"><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times&quot; , &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\"><b><br /></b></span></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"line-height: 115%;\"><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times&quot; , &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\"><b>Men have one X chromosome and\none Y chromosome while women have two X chromosomes. DNA swapping happens\nbetween a pair of chromosomes, and since the Y chromosome doesn't have a pair,\nit can't swap DNA. So patterns stick around for a long time</b></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: small;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></span></div>\n<br />\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"font-size: 13pt; line-height: 115%; mso-ansi-language: EN;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"font-size: 13pt; line-height: 115%; mso-ansi-language: EN;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b><span style=\"color: magenta;\">All life on Earth is\npowered by a process called chemiosmosis, where the chemical adenosine\ntriphosphate (ATP), the rechargeable chemical 'battery' for life, is both\nbroken down and re-formed during respiration to release energy used to drive\nthe reactions of life, or metabolism. </span><o:p></o:p></b></span></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"font-size: 13pt; line-height: 115%; mso-ansi-language: EN;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span></span></div>\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"font-size: 13pt; line-height: 115%; mso-ansi-language: EN;\">\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"font-size: 13pt; line-height: 115%; mso-ansi-language: EN;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b><span style=\"color: blue;\">Earthly phosphorus is\nthe key element in ATP, and other fundamental building blocks of life like\nDNA,&nbsp; is largely insoluble in water and\nhas a low chemical reactivity.</span><o:p></o:p></b></span></span></span></div>\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"font-size: 13pt; line-height: 115%; mso-ansi-language: EN;\">\n</span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"font-size: 13pt; line-height: 115%; mso-ansi-language: EN;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span></span></div>\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"font-size: 13pt; line-height: 115%; mso-ansi-language: EN;\">\n</span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"font-size: 13pt; line-height: 115%; mso-ansi-language: EN;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: red; font-size: large;\"><b>The <span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">complex enzymes SAGALA</span> required for both the creation and break down of ATP came from black meteorite\nstones (<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">Shiva Lingams</span> ) which rained on earth from the sky. &nbsp;This seed containing stone is allegorically called\nLord Shiva\u2019s phallus.</b></span><span style=\"font-size: small;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></span><br />\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"font-size: 13pt; below is in one of my old blogs which I penned 8 years ago<br />\n<br />\n<br />\nDIGRESSION:<br />\n<br />\n<br />\nFour decades ago, when i was a young boy, I took a bus from Mangalore to Mumbai.<br />\n<br />\nOn the passage , the radiator of the bus cracked at midnight somewhere in the middle of no man's land.<br />\n<br />\nI remember, I got hold of another youngster to help me out.<br />\n<br />\nI wanted&nbsp;<b><span style=\"color: red;\">CHOONA</span></b>&nbsp;LIME, SUGAR, FRESH MOTHER'S MILK and RAW KERALA BANANA.<br />\n<br />\nI got everything except the milk.<br />\n<br />\nFinally despite being threatened by the husband of a pretty young lady in burkha nursing a baby, I got the milk.<br />\n<br />\nThis kind and intelligent lady felt that I was doing something right,to save the situation ( in a unsafe area ) and squeezed it into a glass\u2014 despite her husband giving her HAJAAAR tough looks .<br />\n<br />\nThe guy whom I chose to assist me , whispered \u201c Another woman has powder milk-- hum log maar khaane waala hai \u201c<br />\n<br />\nI said \u201c NOPE \u2013that will lack hormones and will NOT make heat resistant strong adhesive putty \u201c<br />\n<br />\nI made a strong adhesive solution which held the hot radiators leak till the next radiator welding workshop in a small town .<br />\n<br />\nChoona was the cement.<br />\n<br />\nSugar was the binder<br />\n<br />\nHormones in fresh \u2013repeat \u2013 fresh mother's milk did the magic catalysis --surprised?<br />\n<br />\nRaw Kerala banana was the resin.<br />\n<br />\nOn ship's which carry corrosive salt we coat the steel of the ship's cargo hold with lime , sugar and cows milk.<br />\n<br />\nAfter that once the salt is discharged, takes at least 300 bars of water pressure from a HP wash Kew machine to get the white compound off the rough steel surface.<br />\n<br />\nSuch a sharp water blade can slice off a human arm clean.<br />\n<br />\ncapt ajit vadakayil<br Having said this , God does not store JUNK inside his creations..<br /><br />Ancient Maharishis had 12 strand DNA\u2014NIL junk. He has immediate access to all information.<br /><br />Vishnu avatars has 13 strand DNA and more, with NIL junk DNA. Vishnu mortals are not reborn.. If they had children they died without procreation.. It is stupidity to say \u201cI am a descendant of Lord Krishna like many CHOOT bhaiyya Yadavs do \u201d..<br /><br />Say, Jew Rothschild of last century, due to his sins was born again in Somalia as a crippled beggar. His JUNK DNA contains information about his previous birth when he was ZE cats whiskers \u2013rich and powerful.. It will contain information when he was an animal or an insect ..<br /><br />ON MOKSHA-- SOUL TRANSMITS ALL INFORMATION TO THE MOTHER FIELD OF BRAHMAN AT THE SEVENT ASTRAL LAYER.<br /><br />This way you can call junk DNA as a SOUL RECORD.<br /><br />Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) is a nucleic acid that contains all the genetic instructions used in the development and functioning of all known living things. The most important role of the DNA is to store information \u2013 a long term storage. DNA is like a computer program but far, far more advanced than any software ever created or will be created..<br /><br />Junk DNA contains information on the trajectory of your soul, which describes how you have come to be who you are..<br /><br />The soul has its own genome ( SAMSKARAS ) ; that is, it carries a complete template of traits that it has developed through the incarnational process, and it also carries, within that same template, the original slate upon which was written its unique identity. Phobias are the result of SOUL SAMSKARAS.<br /><br />Soul samskaras have an effect on your subconscious mind and it affects your choices.<br /><br />Pilgrims go to Sabarimala to surgically remove traumas and debilitating phobias..<br /><br />https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2018/11/5900-year-old-sabarimala-this-planets.html<br /><br />The soul genome, whose template is constantly expanding over the course of its incarnations, contains, in the form of quanta of energy, innumerable bytes of physical information as well as its experiences and interpretations of them.<br /><br />Physical DNA imprints itself into the soul genome, expanding its template through energetic form\u2014they are energy wave forms and holographs.<br /><br />The cumulative history of your soul is dynamic, and continually expanding.<br /><br />The human soul evolves and its frequency rises due to lesser negative karmic baggage . When the soul frequency rises that it is parked at the sixth astral layer\u2014ready for moksha , the JUNK DNA reduces..<br /><br />A jivanmukt with highest soul frequency , has merged his spiritual DNA into his biological DNA \u2014his soul has evolved to its fullest and is now part of the mother field of Brahman, the morphogenetic field of consciousness. After death this deserving soul is liberated from the endless cycle of births..<br /><br />Capt ajit vadakayil<br />..</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n</ol>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-6awa-dPXhDA/TkEEbSQA8CI/AAAAAAAAFOE/YdWQz9y748A/s1600/dark.JPG\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-6awa-dPXhDA/TkEEbSQA8CI/AAAAAAAAFOE/YdWQz9y748A/s1600/dark.JPG\" /></a></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 0pt;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p>&nbsp;CAPT AJIT VADAKAYIL</o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p>..</o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 0pt;\">\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"margin: 0in 0in 10pt;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 0pt;\">\n</div>\n</div>\n<br /></div>\n<br /></div>\n<br /></div>\n", "author": {"id": "14410812789424637654", "displayName": "Capt. text-align: center;\"></div><br />\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"> The oldest example of stainless steel is antiquated as the iron pillar of Delhi erected 1600 years ago by Indian king Kumara Gupta 1. Here the patina or protective layer oxide is not by chromium but by Phosphorous.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div align=\"center\" class=\"separator\" style=\"margin: 0in; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"http://3.bp.blogspot.com/_tugjD0mUn6M/TQJAlgzpb2I/AAAAAAAABo4/MFfx519Nw1c/s1600/ss2.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt; text-decoration: none;\"></span></a><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/_tugjD0mUn6M/TQnrqfR4A3I/AAAAAAAACDc/v_ZRITsIQto/s1600/images.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/_tugjD0mUn6M/TQnrqfR4A3I/AAAAAAAACDc/v_ZRITsIQto/s1600/images.jpg\" /></a></div><div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"http://2.bp.blogspot.com/_tugjD0mUn6M/TQnrtBXp4PI/AAAAAAAACDg/VVtN05XhA2Q/s1600/images+%252829%2529.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"http://2.bp.blogspot.com/_tugjD0mUn6M/TQnrtBXp4PI/AAAAAAAACDg/VVtN05XhA2Q/s1600/images+%252829%2529.jpg\" /></a></div></div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">However the presence of high chromium / nickel rock ore mines in India have ensured that some of the old steel weapons are still intact. Even modern technology has not developed any steel which is completely stain proof or corrosion proof.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Stainless steel is the best for aggressive cargoes and acids.. Stainless steel corrodes in mineral acids, non oxidising acid solutions, reducing acids ( Sulphuric acid of &gt;80% strength is not very aggressive , only medium rage is aggressive due to non-oxidising character ), and hot caustic whose corrosion rate increases with increased temp.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Chlorinated hydrocarbons also called halogenated hydrocarbons by themselves do not attack SS since they are non electrolytes. The dissolving effect they have on organic paint coatings is not possible on SS. It is the impurities which corrode. If the decomposition products are acidic or contain high concentration of chlorides rapid corrosion may occur. </span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Oxidation or hydrolysis (salt + water = acid + base ) reactions between Chorinated HC and residual water can cause corrosion. The water content of Chlorinated HC if greater than 100 ppm corrodes the tank. Oxidation is prevented by inhibitors. Obtain full specs incl impurities. This must include residual water, Chloride and Hydrogen Chloride content. Clean tanks ASAP after discharging. Remember Chlorine ( or inorganic chloride ) in fresh water does not attack SS.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Chromium metal dissolves in Hydrochloric acid and dilute Sulphuric acid at room temperature. But it does not dissolve in HNO3 because of a curious phenomenon known as passivation in which the metal becomes covered with a thin unreactive coating. Ordinary iron gets passivated by Nitric acid due to the formation of Ferroso Ferric Oxide Fe3O4 film on the surface of iron.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">On ships you do not allow crew to enter a SS tank without shoe covers. The idea is not about preventing of dirtying the tank. It is about damaging an armour and contaminating it with the carbon of black sole safety shoes.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Stainless steel depends for its corrosion resistance on the formation of a passive surface film, which is composed, mainly of chromium oxide. Although this film forms spontaneously when the metal is exposed to air or to water, it is possible to damage or contaminate the surface during fabrication or during service so that the ability to form a satisfactory film is impaired. It is necessary to avoid or correct such damage if the optimum corrosion resistance of the stainless is to be obtained. It should be noted that the surface will usually repassivate if the film is damaged- if this were not so, the corrosion resistance of stainless steel would be no better than that of a coated steel. Only when the chromium content of SS is greater than 12% the chromium oxide layer (CrO2)forms.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">The thickness of a well builtup oxide film is about one millionth mm on the surface of stainless steel. The unit is Angstroms which is one divided by ten million of a millimeter. Despite the thinness of this armour provided, it will provide good corrosion resistance. A tank which has been hot washed for long must be allowed to rest before wall wash allowing the Chromium Oxide layer to build up. Since passive layer consists of oxides the stainless steel has to be oxidised to maintain the positive layer. Remember the Chromium Oxide layer is invisible. The film can be destroyed by active metals like iron particles or by oxygen starvation.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">PASSIVATION:</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">A protective armor will form on Austenetic SS only if oxidising condition are present. Nitric acid is a strongly oxidising liquid. Passivating with 14% cold Nitric acid is the best way to build up the chromium oxide layer with 2 hours of contact time. Then the SS has to be rinsed with fresh DI water till the pH is 7. This solution also acts as a thorough cleaning agent for stainless steel, rapidly and selectively dissolving free surface iron while conditioning the surface for self passivation. (do not use Nitric acid greater than 20 percent strength for passivation as the iron contamination will not be removed).</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Conditioning possibly involves anodic oxidation of the surface. The nitrous gases which emanate while recirc in the tanks are toxic and have a delayed effect. Rinsing clean SS in oxygen rich water or storage in open air can also do the trick but it takes too long ( few days ) to develop to the correct thickness . Steel automatically passivates by the action of mother nature. So it is advisable to put 100 litres of fresh water inside a cleaned (to WWT or WW) tank on the ballast passage. Air must be replenished regularly ( no forced ventilation is allowed ).</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Passivation with Nitric acid is usually done prior loading very aggressive chemicals. Passivation is necessary after discharging even moderately aggressive cargoes like Palm fatty acids. Passive SS can be rendered active by dipping in Nitric acid heated to 75 deg c. Hence the reason for cold nitric acid recirc. In circumstances favourable to passivity ss has a potential of near noble metal. If passivity is destroyed SS is no different from ordinary iron. Nitric acid &gt; 20% should not be used for passivation as iron contamination will not be removed. In absolute reality nitric acid removes surface contamination which would interfere with the passive oxide film redeveloping.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Even ordinary iron can be rendered passive by nitric acid due to the formation of Ferroso-ferric oxide layer ( Fe3O4).</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Palladium chloride test for active surfaces:</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Passive steel does not liberate Hydrogen form Sulphuric acid. Palladium can absorb 900 times its own volume of Hydrogen by Adsorbsion and Occlusion. Hydrogen gas reduces Palladium Chloride PdCl2 easily to form black Palladium metal and Hydrogen Chloride.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">H2 + PdCl2 = Pd + 2 HCl</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">This is the reason that Sulphuric acid or HCl must be mixed with palladium chloride if the black precipitate of metal must be seen by the naked eye. Passive SS does not liberate hydrogen. Palladium Chloride results can be tested using a mass spectrometer too.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Rinse PdCl2 with DI water from a squirter as the black spot is active.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">If free iron ( not oxidised iron ) is present on the SS surface the iron is oxidised by Palladium Chloride ( acid reagent solution ) to iron oxide.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">4PdCl2 + 4 H2O + 3 Fe = 4 Pd + 8 HCl + Fe304</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Palladium chloride comes in a small bottle with a dropper. The contact time should be 3 min minimum. The shelf life is one year if you keep it in the fridge in a coloured bottle. Unitor sells it. Palladium chloride crystals or deliquescent powder is soluble in water or alcohol.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Salt spray test: passivation is evaluated by appearance of rust spots.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Copper sulphate test: a galvanic type test in which the more noble copper plays upon less noble iron partcles but not on SS. Patches of copper sulphate shows a poorly passivated surface. Passivated parts are immersed in a Copper Sulfate solution for five minutes, rinsed and visually examined. Any copper (pink) color indicates the presence of free iron and the test is considered unacceptable.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Ferroxyl test: causes coloured iron compounds to appear as specks.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Passiprobe electric test: a mildly corrosive acetate buffer absorbed in a porous test pad i brought in contact with the suspect active SS. The reference passiprobe also contacts the porous medium completing the electrical current for measurement. Surface free iron will cause the passive reading value to go higher in the non noble direction. Remember free iron is not oxidised.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Rust in minute particles can stay suspended in viscous heavy liquids like MEG which can fail a first foot. Rust can accelerate polymerisation.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Passivation Oxyliser meter test: </span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">The passivation meter sets up a temporary corrosion cell. The anode is the stainless steel surface and the cathode is the reference electrode. The electrolyte is a suitable solution for the application and is applied dropwise to a piece of absorbent paper, which is then placed on the steel surface.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">The principle is based on the electrochemical rest potential. This is one of the most direct ways to measure passivity. It is faster and more accurate than palladium chloride. The millivolt scale is from 0 to 100, in passivity units.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">It is used to check the presence of free iron.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Measuring temperature is 15 to 25C</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">The surface to be tested must be free of rust , colours and stains.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Connect the black reference electrode and the red anode clamp to the oxiliser.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Remove the plastic soaker bottle from the tip of the reference electrode and clean tip properly with a tissue.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Connect the red clamp with SS</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Moisten a filter paper strip with the fluid for SS. The paper should be wetted properly. Place this paper on the SS.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Place the tip of the reference electrode on the paper.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">The tip must make good contact with the fluid.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Read off on the LCD display\u2014wait 10 seconds for reading to stabilise.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">&lt;60 low passivity-- and reducing  &gt;60 good passivity.\u2014and increasing</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Steady values upto 90 are possible.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">If after 30 seconds the passivity is reducing\u2014the passivity is not good.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">If the surface contains too much free iron\u2014negative values can be measured.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">If you grind a piece of SS with scotch brite, the surface will be activated and value&lt;30 which will slowly increase can be measured If you scratch the SS with a iron nail &lt;10 and reducing can be measured. The ref electrode should be immersed in 3.8 molar potassium chloride solution.\u2014there is an enclosed soaker bottle filled with KCl for this. Powered by 9V battery. </span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Stainless steel is a general name given to a whole family of high alloyed corrosion resistant steels in which chromium is the main alloying element. It is important that you know the exact type of stainless steel 316L , 316LN etc you have inside your chemical tankers tanks for clad s/steel, solid s/steel ,steam coils , ladders , supports ,pump shell etc. It is widely accepted that under oxidising conditions for steel with a chromium content of at least 12%, an impervious and largely invisible oxide film forms on the surface which is self healing acts as a barrier between the metal and its environment and this effectively reduces corrosion rate. In reducing conditions the film however breaks and the air formed film will not be repaired and corrosion will be enhanced in damaged areas. Chromium improves hardness and wear resistance. </span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">The inclusion of Nickel as alloying element improves the strength and corrosion resistance. </span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">The addition of Molybednum up to 3.5 % will reduce the susceptibility to pitting attack, which could result from the presence of chlorides. Molybdenum improves hardness and reduced enlargement of grain structure. On a parcel tanker it is important to note which tanks have steam coils of higher molybdenum content for cargoes like heated caustic. Stress corrosion occurs in heating coils. Higher mo grades are more resistant to pitting. Molebdenum is soluble in hot concentrations of nitric acid.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Stainless steel is classified according to their crystal structure which is defined in terms of composition and heat treatment into following groups: Martensitic. Ferritic. Austenitic. </span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">When carbon distributes itself evenly in the iron the material is called austenite. It is named after Sir WC Roberts Austen. The austentic stainless steel is generally used in the construction of chemical tankers, since they are compatible with a wide range of cargoes. The austentic grades have good workability and comparatively good weldability. Material formation of austenite group is like a cube. The boundary of the cube is corroded by any carbionic trouble., grain corrosion. Austenitic stainless steel is non magnetic and non heat treatable. The surface of SS is not so bright. </span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">The Molybdenum free grades are 304, 304L and 321 while the molybdneum containing grades are 316, 316L, 316LN or 317 and 317L. The austenatic steel generally consists of C: 0.02 to 0.10 %, Cr: 18 to 25%, Ni: 8 - 22 5, Mo: 0-4%. The notation \u201cn\u201d means it has more nickel for better resistance. </span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">304---Chromium/ 19% Nickel/ 10% Molybdenum/ nil Carbon / 0.08% 316l--- Chromium / 17.5% Nickel / 13% Molybdenum/ 2.7 % Carbon/ 0.03% 317l--- Ch/ 18.5% Ni/ 14.5% Mo/ 3.5% C/ 0.03% 254smo---Ch/ 20% Ni/ 18% Mo/ 6.5% C/ 0.02% Al-6XN--Ch/ 22% Ni/ 25% Mo/ 7% C/ 0.03% </span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">The thermal expansion of stainless steel is higher (1.8 times) compared to mild steel while heat conductivity is lower (40%) and electrical resistivity is greater. There are great possibilities of distorsion and warping due to longer cooling time of SS. Therefore whenever possible clamps and jigs should be used to keep the pieces in line until they have cooled. </span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Certain specific agents such as halides causes a local breakdown of the passive film on the steel surface. This highly localised breakdown followed by electrochemical action results in pitting which rapidly propagates into steel. Chlorides are particularly conducive towards this form of attack even when present in minute quantity. Pitting hole is like a bulb and is difficult to detect without a dye penetrant.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Collection of solid sludges on the surface of stainless steel may also result in pitting. When sludge is known to be present in certain type of cargoes, means of circulating the cargo should be provided e.g Phosphoric acid. </span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Crevice corrosion occurs with chemicals containing chlorides and other halogen ions. Rapid corrosion will occur in narrow crevices / geometric irregularities in the metal surface where oxygen cannot gain access. It is essential to design tanks with this in mind. All welds are smooth finish and all spatter is removed. Different electric potential can exist on metal surface with anode rapidly corroding and perforating. Stress corrosion may be defined as the fracture of a component by the conjoint action of a tensile stress in a corrosive environment. The failure of this is confined to environments containing either Sodium Hydroxide, Sulphides, Halides and mainly Chlorides. Chlorides are particularly conducive to this form of attack and cracking, which is transgranular is found most frequently in the ph range of 3 to 8. Cracking associated with caustic solutions may be either trans or granular and is usually confined to solutions of high conc and with temperatures in excess of 60C. Causic embrittlement is the corrosion resulting in cracking of steel stressed beyond its yield point due to localised concentrations of hydroxide ions breaking down the cohesion between the ferrite grains. If the steel is heated in the temperature range of 500 to 850C the carbon may precipitates as Chromium Carbide at the grain boundaries. These areas become denuded of chromium and the protective oxide film is prevented from forming. Steel in this condition is termed as \"sensitised\" and on exposure to a corrosive environment will suffer localised attack at the grain boundaries. During welding some regions in the parent metal near the weld will reach temperatures in the sensitised range, and subsequent exposure to a corrosive environment the steel will be susceptible to this form of attack. This is also known as weld decay. This can be generally avoided by using steel with carbon content below 0.03% max, and addition of elements with a stronger affinity for carbon than chromium like titanium or niobium. </span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Solid stainless steel: the tanks are built of full stainless steel plates. Usually the corrugated forward and aft bulkheads are made of solid steel. </span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Clad steel: the term clad steel refers to a mild steel base plate to which a thinner layer ( 3mm ) of a stainless steel is continously and integrally bonded. In this way cost of vessel could be reduced. The mild steel side is used in water ballast tanks and the difficulties of bimettalic corrosion in connection with the use of solid stainless steel are avoided. The clad steel is formed by: Roll cladding. Explosive bonding. </span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Cutting: Cold cutting: solid stainless steel plates are often cold sheared to size. Hot cutting: Flame cutting with flux or iron powder injection Plasma arc cutting. The oxy- acetylene flame cannot be used due to the formation of a highly refractory chromium oxide at the interface. But with fluxing agents injected into the cut the smothering oxide is rapidly removed and fresh surfaces are continuously exposed. Clad steel may be mechanically sheared to size, but this should be carried out with clad side uppermost so that any burr will be on the carbon steel side. When flame cutting it should be done from the carbon steel side. Note: after gas cutting the edges should machined or grounded to clean all scale prior welding. Plasma arc can cut SS upto 10 cms thick with temperatures 11000 deg c to 28000 deg c.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Welding: A correct procedure and correct consumables should be used for welding of stainless steel to prevent weld joints to crack. It is important that the heat input during welding is kept low to ensure a small heat affected zone and exposure to the sensitising temperature range for the shortest possible time. Spatter and rough surfaces can result in local breakdown in passivity resulting in pitting. Precautions should be taken before welding commences to prevent any spatter formed from adhering to the surface adjacent to the weld by employing masking tape or by applying suitable temporary coating. The welds should be smooth free from porosity, inclusions and cavities and carried by competent welders. </span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Welding of solid stainless steels:  For butt welds the vee preparation has been used successfully in the construction of ships tanks for both flat and vertical positions. Some times for welding of thick plates copper backing bars are used. The copper backing bars extracts heat during welding and also gives profile to the root bead. In order to avoid distortions for thicker plates double V preparation with separate runs deposited alternately one on each side of the joint is used. </span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Welding of clad steel:  Welding of clad steel plates generally involves separate treatment procedures for steel base and cladding material. The weld deposit for the backing plate must at least match the strength of the carbon steel parent material. The usual practice is to choose an electrode, which would be used, if the cladding was not present. If this carbon steel weld metal comes in contact with the corrosion resistant cladding, the weld material will be diluted by the alloy and the deposit is likely to be hard and brittle. This problem is offset by using of filler materials having alloy contents greater than those of the parent stainless steel. Generally the first weld made from carbon steel backing side should penetrate to the stainless cladding but not into this layer. The backing side should be completed before chipping back to clean metal on the clad side. Sufficient metal should be removed to allow at least two runs of alloy weld metal to be deposited. The first two runs are made by using filler materials having alloy contents greater than those of the parent stainless steel. For subsequent runs should be made with a view to ensuring that the deposited metal matches the composition of the clad material and that the properties are not impaired. For thin gauge material the total plate thickness may be welded with electrodes comparable in composition with cladding material.</span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"> Generally all the fusion welding process like manual arc welding with covered electrodes, metal inert gas or tungsten inert gas welding technique could be used for welding stainless steel joints. Submerged arc welding is suitable for thickness greater than 10 mm. The saw process gives high heat input hence it is essential that the parent steel grade has a very low carbon content. Light gauge electrodes and a low welding current should be used. With multipass welding the interpass temperature should be less than 100C in order to reduce the possibility of precipitation of grain boundary carbides. Many of the processes used in tank construction affect the passivity of the surface. The metal surface near welds oxidises during the welding operation and the oxide films produced are less protective than the normal film. </span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">The commonest types of surface contamination which can lead to localised pitting in corrosive environments are: Embedding of matter such as iron and iron dust in to the surface. This causes pitting, pores in welds and rough surfaces. Entrapment of slag weld metal. Weld spatter- particles of slag and weld metal (from the welds in the tank itself or from structures adjacent to the tank adhering to the metal surface. Coloured oxide films near welds - these result in a dechromised surface beneath the film. Splashes of paint etc which may stick to the surface with formation of crevices. </span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Care during fabrication: Contamination of the surface by iron, rust etc can be minimised by: Keeping the surface of stainless steel covered. Placing sheets of hardboard over the ss when it is being shaped by rolling. Coating surface with anti spatter before welding, which are readily removed after fabrication. Stainless steel wire brushes for deslagging etc should be used. A set of cutting tools / hand grinders + wheels should be separately kept exclusively for stainless steel work they should be suitably colour coded. As far as possible the handling of carbon steel and stainless steel on the same work tables and in same work shops should be avoided. The stainless steel work place should be separately demarcated. Do not put any carbon steel / rusted equipment on the surface during fabrication. The carbon steel tools to be avoided on the surface. Men engaged on stainless steel work should not be permitted to use steel shot footwear. </span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">As far as possible handling of stainless steel and carbon steel on the same working surfaces and in the same work areas should be avoided. Also prefabrication of stainless steel should be preferably take place in areas which are free from carbon steel dust. If grit blasting is applied then only clean sand or grit, uncontaminated by iron or rust should be used. On no account the stainless steel surface shouldbe shot blasted. Handling equipment such as slings, hooks and lift trucks forks should be protected with clean wood, cloth or plastic buffers to reduce contact with iron surfaces. </span><span style=\"color: black; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div><u1:p></u1:p><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><br />\n</div><div style=\"line-height: 13.5pt; margin: 0in;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;\">Final cleaning: Although careful attention to the procedures described above will minimise surface contamination, it is impossible to avoid this completely and some final surface treatment, normally involving acid pickling and washing is necessary.this procedure is often referred to as 'passivation' implying that some form of protective, film is developed on the metal surface. In reality, however, this treatment is to remove surface contamination which would interfere with the passive film normally developed on the stainless steels.
